												A terribly flawed game. Graphics were dated, even upon release. The car handling is vague and unresponsive, even on hardcore mode. The story is awful. Once you adjust to the vague controls, there is a true sense of speed when cruising through the mountains, or beaches, or canyons, or through the city. Though games like Forza Horizon do offer a better overall experiance. TDU2 offers true driving freedom.  Even with the dated graphics, this game can be truely beautiful. 												Hello and welcome to my review of the relatively old game Test Drive Unlimited 2.I am aware of the fact that the game was released in 2011, I've purchased it in 2013 and I will still review this title because the series are discontinued and I do still enjoy the game untill today.Now something about me regarding the racing genre on PC.I do not like racing games where you can race on a track, in a car which is almost unhandle-able ( in my opinion, ofcourse ).With these games I mean Grid, and partially Dirt.Okay, I did enjoy Dirt 3 and Dirt Showdown without a doubt but in the end, playing with a controller or a steering wheel, it didn't satisfy me enough to keep me playing these titles once in a week or more often.So now back to what I do enjoy in a game of the racing genre.I do really like the open-world idea, having a big map or several maps ( In Test Drive's case: Island ).Driving around without anything forcing you do to anything, making speed and just drive all across the island on various landscapes with a nice sight does satisfiy me.Buying a relaxing car, my Ferrari 458 Italia, Purple with black rims in this case: And just cruising around the island, on the roads with water to the right of me and the city to the left of me, hearing the engine doing it's work is what I like.Not being forced to drive a track, do a race and aiming on finishing first without anything else you can do.Just free-roaming in open worlds with customizable cars which you can upgrade and adjust to any specification you want.And that's for the driving part, now for the experience in terms of sound.The sound of the car, in various situations ( Driving in sand, dirt, or just a normal road ).The sound is different every time, for every car in any situations ( weather too for example ) is just perfect in the game and these small things help me enjoy the game more than I already did.Driving through a tunnel while It's raining in my custom white Nissan GT-R is what I can't do in any other game.And these elements of Test Drive is what makes me want to play the game, the endless options to tune and adjust cars to exactly how I'd like to and then going on the road, hearing the right sound and feeling good when playing the game .. Yeah, that;Now for the other part of the game:Missions, Money, Houses and avatar.Missions in Test Drive are tasks you have to complete which can be anything from getting a high adrenaline bar, but also could be driving above a certain speed and also opposite missions like driving really careful without the person next to you in the car getting sick.These missions are pretty fun for the first few times but become boring quick, but they reward you with money to buy cars, houses and clothing.Money in the game is pretty important ofcourse but I feel like you just have to keep grinding the repetitive missions to finally buy the car you have been wanting for a while.So yeah, the method of money making within the game is something I don't like and that made me want to Cheatengine myself a couple houndred million instead of working for the money I want to buy the car I'd like.Houses and Avatar: Besides the garage part to store your cars, I don't care about Houses or pimping your avatar ( Buying clothes, getting haircuts, etc ).So yup, the car driving part is what I like the most of the game.Okay, for some of you I might have not played the game in the right way, or not long enough but this was my final review of the game.If I had to give the game a score from 0 to 100 I would give it a 85, some aspects could've been done way better ( Money making and missions ) but the driving itself is what makes the game a good open-world cruising game, and pretty unique in it's genre.Okay okay, Grand Theft Auto is somewhat more bigger and to some also better but what I care about is the car driving.In Grand Theft Auto the car driving is only fun when stunting and such with your friends.So that's it for the review guys, I hope you have enjoyed reading my opinion about this game.

First of all close the game.-- Those of you who do not know what Troubleshooting compatibility is, search up for some helpful tips on Google! :) –- Yes you guessed it! You are going to be using Compatibility to get the game working, note: you only need to do this once!Firstly: goto your game library, locate TDU2, right click the game and select Properties, goto the Local files tab, click Browse local filesSecondly: Locate these 2 files: TestDrive2.exe and UpLauncher.exe. Right-click each one separately, click on “Troubleshoot Compatibility”, click “Troubleshoot program”, check “The program worked in earlier versions of Windows but won’t install or run now” -> click next, Select Windows 8 -> click Next, click “Test the program...” (needed to save the new settings) -> close the app after it opens -> Click next, click “Yes, save the settings for this program” -> Click “Close”. 												As my car hurtles over the tallest cliff in Hawaii, I take one last look in the rear-view mirror. How did it come to this? For the longest time I was just another loser, content with a mundane life and those brief moments of escapism. Somehow over the course of nearly 30 hours in Test Drive Unlimited 2, I became a monster. Sometimes when people play videogames, it's to get away, like a virtual vacation. But there are those times, where I don't want to be a plumber, a rodent with an attitude, a criminal, or Laura Bailey. I just want to drive around in expensive automobiles. In the real world I own two cars, one of them has a busted alternator. The other? No brakes. Despite being unable to start or stop, I've maintained the same driving job for the past decade. I'm always driving through the same neighborhoods meeting the same people every moment of every day. On top of all that, if Florida is considered America's♥♥♥♥♥♥ then I live in one of its hemorrhoids. But hey, all I need is an hour or two a day of wonderfully escapist adventures and I'm golden.I was a fan of Test Drive Unlimited 1 on the Xbox 360. The handling wasn't particularly good, but the atmosphere and sense of exploration was excellent. With a few fixes, better graphics, and more content, it could be my ideal driving game. I'm not sure what I was expecting with the sequel. I read all of the reviews, noted that there are major problems such as Securom, dysfunctional servers, and so on. I considered the possibility that this game might not even work. But I gave it a shot anyway......I'm at a party...alright..cool I guess. Apparently I'm a woman now. It's just like Skyrim except I'm wearing clothes and I don't think I have a six-foot-long p-."PepsimanVsJoe! Enjoying your birthday party?"Oh It's my birthday? I had no idea. Apparently I'm a silent-protagonist so all I can do is smile."Come check out your gift! It's a brand new car!"No way! This is one of those end-game vehicles. I must be dreaming. This is so totally meta.Sure enough the real game begins, I lose my job, only to get an offer to join a racing group for some show called Solar Crown. This is so ridiculous. I head to the used car dealer for my first actual virtual vehicle. "HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥" I say to myself.The dealer? He has small hands. The driving school instructor? A regular Alex Smith. It's no wonder none of them have gone for a handshake, it would be like if I held up my finger so a baby could grab it. After sleep-driving through my first test I say "Thank you very much." to the instructor. Apparently I'm a very-thankful-and-not-quite-silent protagonist. The only words I ever say are to express gratitude. On the road, the handling is...well it's about as bad as TDU1. In my mind that's good enough, because I'm finally living the dream again, cruising through hundreds of miles of beautiful Ibiza, and eventually Hawaii. As with the previous game, everyone needs help getting around the islands. There's the drunk guy who wants me to speed, the sick girls that throw up if I slam on the brakes, the random woman who always calls me adorable, and...wait a minute. It's happening again isn't it? The same people, requesting me to do the same favors for them over and over. Don't they have anything to say? While I'm driving we could discuss those bonus features on DVDs, or what tiny-handed men are good for aside from making origami birds out of starburst wrappers. Instead it's always "I'm going to be late!" or "I just broke a nail" or "Whoa ho! Look at that speed!"The people I compete with are slightly more developed, but it's also a facade. Miami Harris is little more than an untimely Paris Hilton joke. Then there's the Wilder brothers. Oh look at us! We're so extreme...ly shallow! Tess Wintory never figures out her daddy issues. Her dad Stuart is just a useless old prick. If I'm expected to race against these jerks all the time, at least a little effort could have been expended to develop them. But who am I to talk? I have the least character development of all. Oh sure, I've bought several houses, over a dozen cars, and a couple wardrobes. I've also gotten plastic surgery so many times I've forgotten what I originally looked like. In fact I just got some work done earlier today. The nose wasn't right.Aside from a few minor changes and additions, TDU2 isn't really much of a sequel. In some ways it's even a step back. Motorcycles are locked behind a DLC wall. The races are organized in a Grand Prix setup, with the winner being the person who attains the most points. However that model is dumped for the major championships races because....???? It doesn't make any sense. A casino would have been nice to hang out at, but that's also DLC. All of the other additions seem to be multiplayer-centric, which is pointless when half the people that buy this game can't even get it to work.But does any of that truly matter to me? I got what I wanted right? My virtual fantasy of owning expensive cars, several houses (that I can't interact with), and free reign over a beautiful...but lifeless island. Lifeless except for the same 12-15 idiots who sit around impotently while I drive them around or beat them to the ground in the championships. Nearly 30 hours of this dream has become a nightmare, and I suspect that it won't end anytime soon.So where we did leave off? Oh right...I was hurtling over the tallest cliff in Hawaii. Yes, I'm throwing it all away. Soon it will all be-I hit the rocks, then the water...suddenly I'm back on the road again...my car is a little scratched but it isn't even wet. I knew it wouldn't work anyway, but can you blame me for trying? It's that time again. I remove the bandages from my last trip under the knife and check the rear-view mirror. The nose still isn't right.

												I've poured a significant chunk of time into this game, and as far as I can tell, it was all a bit of a waste.This game appears, from the screenshots and trailer, to be a relatively straightforward driving sim, with an ambitious goal of giving you hundreds of kilometers of road to drive on, and loads of cars. It certainly delivers on giving you a beautiful and detailed set of cars (There's geometry in the stitched leather of my Alfa Romeo's dashboard, for goodness' sake!), and an enormous amount of road to play with them on.Unfortunately, it suffers in a few fairly glaring areas.Area 1: Voice "Acting"There is a serious problem with the way the voice actors were either directed or hired, as the voice acting cannot be more irritating, repetitive and off-key. The dialogue is pretty awful, and the "story" which attempts to make an excuse for you entering loads of "championships" consisting of the same eight or so opponents would have been better off dropped from the game.(Additionally, if you don't play with a male character, prepare to be perpetually misgendered as they only recorded dialogue using masculine pronouns.)Area 2: DLC HellThe game is littered with "DLC" cars which you can gawk at in full detail, get in, and test drive, but which, as far as I can tell, cost Atari Points to unlock the privilege of purchasing with in-game currency. Good work guys.Also, about 40% of the customisation options for your character, houses and vehicles are literally unrelated Atari logos and trademarks. What a load of crap.Area 3: PhysicsI wouldn't call myself an expert in car handling or physics, I don't have real-life racing experience, the closest I could say I've come is playing a reasonable amount of Gran Turismo, and driving a fairly mundane vehicle around city streets IRL, but to call the physics in Test Drive Unlimited 2 uninviting would be an understatement.So yes, I'm expecting some oversteer and some understeer, maybe if I turn driving aids off I'm expecting to have to pay a little more attention to how I accelerate and steer. Fine.But don't make a game where the vehicle's reaction to the road seems to be dependent on my camera position. Cars have literally flipped backwards after a crest when in cockpit camera, but don't do so from behind. I can only assume that it puts priority on physics objects which are in your view? Makes no damned sense.Likewise, cars feel very detached from the road. There's a definite difference in grip between bitumen and grass, which is fair enough, but cars still slide (forwards) on the tarmac. There's also a "bonus" system for "drifting", though "drifting" doesn't appear to actually be possible due to the game's physics setup. I gave up on that mechanic.Area 4: AIWhen in a time trial style event, with just your vehicle on the track, the time to beat is just barely attainable if you make 0 mistakes, and pretty much impossible if you mess up even once.Meanwhile, in a race with multiple vehicles on the road, your opponents drive like your grandmother going to pick up groceries. They weave in and out of corners in a perfect row with no apparent intent to win. If you do get ahead of them, you can simply slow down in front of them, they won't attempt to overtake and break their racing line at all. Completely stupid. If you're going to ask me to win races, at least make it a challenge rather than wasting my time like this.ConclusionFriends don't let friends buy Atari products.How I Played* Female Character* Microsoft Xbox 360 Wireless Controller with genuine Microsoft controller adaptor* @1920x1200 on a GTX260 (Earlier)* @2560x1440 on a GTX670* Did not purchase any offered DLC* Attempted to use the Unofficial Patch, but unpacking negatively affected ongoing game performance

												Well what makes me come back to this game time and again? Interesting story... no, great driving physics...no, interesting characters.. dont let me start on that, voice acting?.. you could say that if you were entertained by the repeating announcement that apparently the Wilder brother are squabbling with Stewart again (who-tf is Stewart I can only guess). However this game has something. You have you car and the freedom to travel around two islands full of nice sights and sunny vistas. You can drive for hours, buy cars, houses or just explore at your leasure.  You can challenge other people whos worlds seamlesly intersect with yours like in Dark Souls. Or you can explore the world without invisible bounds around the roads, a bit like Skyrim in Cars. But even if you stop, the environment doesn't look as generic as for example in Need for Speed or Driver series, so you are really motivated to visit new places.The graphics are great, there is a weather and day/night cycle. The views you get out of some of your Flats/Houses are amasing. The challenges a varied and exciting. There are also a pair of races around the Island, that can take nearly a real-world hour to complete. I mean if I think about it a bit more, this game is the opposite of what I really don't like about other racing games whith dumb driving on the same track over and over again with an extreme example being american Nascar where you just drive in a circle.Sure the characters look like dorks and sound even worse, but then you see the attention do detail the developers put into the game and it's amazing.  Just try to explore the starting location. You will not see it any more after the first minute or so in-game but the effort put into it speaks for itself. If you take your time and look around at the nicely textured babes, whose breast actually bounce around a bit (in a racing game!), the bar with actually some bottles stuffed behind the counter, then you really get into this holiday Ibiza mood. Did I mention  I really appreciate that detail? There are also many cars each with detailed interior, which you can admire.This game however is not without its (many) problems, to name a few:- the characters are just plain silly and the story even more so- you have to set the controls just so, or the driving experience will be awfull- the driving physics could be much better (I miss dirt 2)- there are no pedestrians (to drive over :)  ) anywhere!- the developer is not in business any moreWell thats my 2c, you can get this game really cheap for less tha $10 on steamtrades, so if you just like to drive around, explore and do an occasional race, this is a game for you!P.S. The Characters in this game are ridiculous and remind me of mega shark vs giant octopus movie. They either creep you out, like the same guy you pick at 2 am in car who is "late for his meeting" or make you laugh hystericly because their dialogs dont correspond with the situation at hand.Also I think this game in not effectively playable with a keyboard.  Good Start , Bad End The game was released in 2011. I absolutley loved TDU1 ,so i decided to buy this one. At the start i was amazed.The Graphics , The Gameplay , The 2 Maps. Everything was great except my PC. Which could run the game with only 45 fps...The game started its lifetime very well. It had alot of cars, Great multiplayer/online , casino , appartments , garrages and all the stuff that one good open world racing game needs. 1 Year after release they announced  The Bike DLC . I was so excited about it. It came out and it was good. The problem was , that u had to buy every bike individually. On that time the multiplayer was working , singleplayer was great and everything was done well for this game so far. But then the problems came. Gameplay/AI The Gameplay/AI had few problems:  Driving Licenses , Cops and Controlls.   Driving License: The problem is that some of the challenges , are too hard to complete or even impossible for some players. Without Driver License u cant progress through the higher rank races.   Cops: Just like the Driver License , here with the cops ... its too hard to outrun them. I like challenges , but for some players this is hell. They are always stoped by the cops , no matter what they do.  Controlls: For the players with wheels this is not a problem. But for players who use keyboard its really hard to drive. In TDU1 was better optimized to drive with keyboard.  Community  Just like the most of the games , they have good community base behind them. There was great  Mods  released by the community moders. It added more cars , skins and everything that one mod can add to the game. But then some "Bad Modders" decided to ruin the fun for the most of the players. From this moment ...  The problems started  Late Multiplayer Problems and Site Problems/Closed Studio However , after the good start with the DLC's and Multiplayer , the problems kicked in.  "The Bad Modders"  developed hacks. That ruined the multiplayer pretty much. For example u are driving Bugatti Veyron with 400 km/h and some guy with subaru drives by u with 500 km/h. It impossible.  Even after that , players were still playing the game.  However in 2014 the site was broken. New players couldn't register their accounts , so they couldn't even play the multiplayer. The multiplayer servers were down every week. It was unplayable. In later 2015 , Atari announced they are quiting TDU Studio. That was the end of TDU.  Overall  I dont recommend this game , even on sale. Its just not worth it. So many problems and bad gameplay. The only good  thing left from this game is the singleplayer mods. Developers did nothing , to even try to fix their game from the hackers.3/10 Not recommended NOTE: The servers may be still working , but its not worth it. U will get only bad server connection and u wont get any new content. Buy at your own risk.

												One of the greatest driving games, that sadly you may never play. I have owned this game a little over 3 weeks and have made/met 18 of the coolest friends in that short time plus an absolute bucket load of friends using the retail version. I'll cut to the bad news first. Firstly you have to make an account at http://www.testdriveunlimited2.com to be able to play this game and to buy DLC. Secondly, Eden games made this and unfortunately for what ever reson went belly-up. Atari luckily stepped in and took the game over but clearly they haven't got the server side stuff in control. This means you get things like:- Losing friends out of your profile and then sometimes they re-appear.- You can buy DLC and then have them turn into mardi gras pink mustangs ( no joke they are vehicles won through a one on one duel with a campaign progress character).-Some of the MMO aspects of the game fail or get broken regularly, meaning that you won't be able to find and join your buds or invite them to things like games in the casino or to your houses or for just a free-ride drive.- If you want to get the casino and or drive a range of cars and bikes you have to buy Atari points at the TDU2 website which is a turn off for many people to say the least because it can be tedious although myself, I never had any issues with it.The Casino DLC is $10AUD and cars work out to be $1AUD each @ $5AUD for 400 Atari points (Pay by Paypal for less hassle). These things are the worst parts of the game and some come and go as mentioned.Great things about the game:- You drive in an open world and work your way through getting licenses for different classes of vehicles and events on the islands of Ibiza and Hawaii. - Meet a lot of great people and make friends with people all over the world (personally I dont even have a problem with non english players) I just ask them, 'you use Steam? Add me as friend :)' even if they don't use the Steam version some make Steam accounts and add the game to non-Steam shortcuts. Then its easy, the add me and I have Google Translate open in the Steam in game browser so they can talk to me in their own language outside of in game chat, problem solved! :) - Did I mention Bikes? :D- Huge amount of Cars (some are DLC), unfortunately only 3 Bikes (DLC), huge array of clothing and customisations to your character by the use of plastic surgeon and to your cars by paintshops and tuning upgrades, a Casino and many properties that you can buy to house your vehicles. I totally dig the MMO aspect of this game even in it's breaks a lot state. The game graphics may not look as good as say Grid2 but that never bothered me, I like the open world aspect and MMO of the game. I've bought almost all the DLC for the game too because I think the game is worth it especially when you snag it for $5 and there are ways to deal with stuff when the Atari/TDUlife servers break etc like the Steam adding to compensate as I mentioned. Also I should mention that my X-Box controller works very well for me in this game and the game does support a fair amount of G' series wheels but you might want to Google the game to find out for sure if it supports yours.I dedicate this review to all the great people I have met in the game, they 'make' the game in my opinion. Also I'm going to put up some of the screenshots I have and will hopefully get the time to make a Youtube tribute to the game if not also my friends. It may be some time for TDU3 to come out and fingers crossed it will be for PC too. I won't wait around like I did getting this game I wished I'd bought it last Christmas. One other thing. Don't or avoid buying DLC vehicles (Google TDU2 DLC vehicles list so you know which they are) you didn't pay for with Atari points when the servers get attacked/modified and become unlocked to buy with just cash. You need to have unlocked them with Atari points in game and or purchased at the TDU2 website because at some stage they will revert to pink Mustangs only worth around $25k. $1.5 million exotic car turning into a $25k pink Mustang....not cool and you'll just be throwing in game cash away. Also, back your game save up periodically not that I've had any save game corruptions as of yet but there are many who claim they lost all they're game progress. The game saves literally everytime you go to the menu and when you quick travel so maybe that was fixed. Better to be safe than sorry I guess but to be honest I only started religiously backing them up when my Ducati that I legimately got with Atari points turned into a Mustang. Its not happened again with any other vehicle since and I did just rebuy it after selling the Mustang.

												This is the closest thing to Forza Horizon on PC... for better or worse. And trust me, the worse is pretty bad. But first, the better.The game is spread across multiple hawaiian islands, in an open world campaign, which is pretty awesome. It also has a great selection of cars, missions, races and other things to participate in, such as painting your cars and altering your avatars appearance, clothing and hairstyle. So far, so good, the game really can be quite fun. I'd rate the physics as either one of the most realistic arcade games I've played, or one of the least realistic simcades I've played. But on to the negatives.The game rarely works without modification, I had to use a standalone launcher (which takes away my ability to gain Steam achievements) to make the game work consistantly. Even still, I can only play a couple hours before the game crashes. But really... I'm ok with that. I'll tell you now what really, truly infuriates me.There are certain timed missions in the game, that are absolutely, positively impossible to complete without driving like a balls to the wall, completely suicidal  lunatic. Take Mad Max style driving, and turn it up my 5. Then, add to that the fact that the most unpredictable traffic in the world is included, and the customer who's car you're delivering doesn't want it scratched, or driven off road, and welcome to the most utterly infuriating racing game ever known to man. I literally can't tell you the number of times that all I've needed to complete a mission is one more damn second, and everything would have been fine. But the game creators set time limits that apparently only God would be able to achieve, because not only must you be a driving god, you must also be the luckiest son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ in the world for traffic not to cut you of and screw up your entire damn race.Now, I know the above paragraph is utterly critical, and even hateful of the game, but I still recommend it... especially on sale. I bought the game for $5, and I've gotten my moneys worth out of it already. I just really wish these particular missions were not made so freaking impossible. The other 95% of the game is fantastic, but that 5% of the games missions completely, and utterly infuriates me. Other than that (and the instability, and utter lack of reliable online support, and need to launch the game through a third party launcher) the game is pretty fun. Just be sure to pick up the universal launcher so you can play offline.http://i-knyazev.ru/tools/tdu2-universal-launcher/

												This game at release had so many issues. The fact is, this game looked great when viewing videos and screenshots or artwork. After several patches leading upto the game before Atari shutdown teams that worked on such projects, the game slowly died but fan's tried hard to keep it a-float. Infact, the fan base was the only thing that kept this game alive.Now, the game is full of cheaters, hackers and modders. There is no technical support or admins. The hackers can ram you full speed and won't be knocked over, only you will go flying. Just one of the many bad things that commonly happen now. Oh, & thats if you're lucky enough to even get this game working. I bought this game for my friends, was it install & play? No, infact, it was so fustrating that both my friends gave up and only me and one friend got to truily test this game out.From my experience, the open world was a great idea, the level up system, cash system & club system was very exciting. All of this if you're lucky to get it to work. And if you can't get the launcher to do it's thing, the next big issue you'll probly have is registration and trying to connect to the server.I simply CANNOT say BUY this game, as it's not worth the hassle. I do say however, avoid at all costs. The game will soon be terminated and i'm glad I got to experience this game first hand before it turned to the largest pile of rubbish I've seen by far.Sound FX is good, only two radio stations and no custom radio support. (Fake radio stations) Graphics were also good for it's time. The first Person view is also nice. Some aspects really catch you're eyes and other aspect ruin you're experience completly.Now lets get to some more dirt. If you and a friend is lucky enough to even get it working together, once in the game, you'll be lucky to even see one another as both vanish and sometimes, only you can see your friend while your friend can't see you or the other way around, very fustrating when you want to free drive open world with friends.The good things about this game is actually not as much as you'd think. Logo's offical, the open world, huge, drivng physics, not the best. But when it comes to cup races or setting up events or local races, this seemed to work well. Cups are Singleplayer, not Multiplayer so some things within the game step on the M.O.O.R they claimed it to be. With all the problems, and the time and effort I had to put into this game made me not wanna recommend or suggest this game to anyone after my bad experiences with it.When the community offers you mods, unoffical pacthes, fixes, or cheats, you ahould clue-in & know there is a problem with this game. Also, you want to sit in you're friend car? you can do this, only if you are GREEN for UPNP and ports, if NAT is red, you simply might not be-able to play. In other words, the less security you have, the better chances you have at playing. And trust me, this was no easy task for people with tight security. lolI honestly couldn't recommend this game even in 2012 after I did actual recommend it to friends, after that, my opinion on this game had changed. I still help people to get this game working and thats the most fustrating problem about this game. Some users are lucky and get it working first try, guess what, it means you are not protected as well as you think & are open for attacks, and if you allow the ports, and the launcher still says NAT in red, this means you're networking hub / router isn't as secure or protective as you think allowing open connections once in a while.
